description: From French accompagnement; equivalent to accompany +â€Ž -ment. First attested in 1744.

entries.meaning: (music) A part, usually performed by instruments, that gives support or adds to the background in music, or adds for ornamentation; also, the harmony of a figured bass.
examples: Brooks performed a saxophone solo on stage, with Robert as accompaniment on the bass.

entries.meaning: That which accompanies; something that attends as a circumstance, or which is added to give greater completeness to the principal thing, or by way of ornament, or for the sake of symmetry.
examples: Synonyms: attachment, supplement; see also Thesaurus:adjunct
A side salad is a common accompaniment to a main dish.
